doc.stem:
Use a Taylor series expansion to derive a centered finite-difference approximation to the third derivative that is second-order accurate. To do this, you will have to use four different expansions for the points xi − 2, xi − 1, xi + 1, and xi + 2. In each case, the expansion will be around the point xi . The interval Δx will be used in each case of i − 1 and i + 1, and 2Δx will be used in each case of i − 2 and i + 2. The four equations must then be combined in a way to eliminate the first and second derivatives. Carry enough terms along in each expansion to evaluate the first term that will be truncated to determine the order of the approximation.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can the numerical differentiation be applied for unequally spaced data?

worksheet.stem:
Find the first derivative of the function using the M-file developed. (Round the final answers to four decimal place.)

 

The values of the first derivative of the function at different values of x are as follows:

 

x First derivative
0.6 __a__
1.5 __b__
1.6 __c__
2.5 __d__
3.5 __e__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file for unequally spaced data is given below.

 

function dy=diffuneq(x,y)
% diffuneq: differentiation of unequally-spaced data
%  dy=diffuneq(func,x,es,maxit,varargin):
% input:
%   x = vector of independent variable
%   y = vector of dependent variable
% output:
%   dy = vector of derivative estimates

if nargin<2,error('at least 2 input arguments required'),end
n=length(x);
for i = 1:n
    dy(i) = dyuneq(x, y, n, x(i));
end
end

 


function dydx=dyuneq(x, y, n, xx)
if xx <= x(2)
    dydx = DyDx(xx, x(1), x(2), x(3), y(1), y(2), y(3));
elseif xx >= x(n - 1)
    dydx = DyDx(xx, x(n - 2), x(n - 1), x(n), y(n - 2), y(n - 1), y(n));
else
    for ii = 2:n - 2
        if xx >= x(ii) & xx <= x(ii + 1)
            if xx - x(ii) < x(ii+1) - xx
                %if the unknown is closer to the lower end of the range,
                %x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
                dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
                    y(ii), y(ii + 1));
            elseif xx - x(ii-1) == x(ii+1)-xx & x(ii)-x(ii-1)<x(ii+2)-x(ii+1)
                %if the unknown is at the midpoint of the range
                % and if the interval below the range
                %is less than the interval above the range,
                %x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
                dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
                    y(ii), y(ii + 1));
            else
                %otherwise, x(ii+1) is chosen as the middle point
                dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii), x(ii + 1), x(ii + 2), y(ii), y(ii + 1), ...
                    y(ii + 2));
            end
            break
        end
    end
end
end

 

function dy=DyDx(x, x0, x1, x2, y0, y1, y2)
dy = y0 * (2 * x - x1 - x2) / (x0 - x1) / (x0 - x2) ...
     + y1 * (2 * x - x0 -x2) / (x1- x0) / (x1 - x2) ...
      + y2 * (2 * x - x0 - x1) / (x2 - x0)/ (x2 - x1);
end

 

The program can be applied to the data with the following script:


>> x=[0.6 1.5 1.6 2.5 3.5];
>> fx=[0.9036 0.3734 0.3261 0.08422 0.01596];
>> dydx=diffuneq(x,fx)


dydx =
 -0.6936  -0.4846  -0.4526  -0.1738  0.0373

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function that computes first- and second-derivative estimates of order O(h2) based on the given formulas. The function’s first line should be set up as function [dydx, d2ydx2] = diffeq(x,y) where x and y are input vectors of length n containing the values of the independent and dependent variables, respectively, and dydx and d2ydx2 are output vectors of length n containing the first-derivative and second-derivative estimates at each value of the independent variable. The function should generate a plot of dydx and d2ydx2 versus x. Have your M-file return an error message if the input vectors are not the same length, or the values for the independent variable are not equally spaced.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The velocity at t = [a(2)] s is [a(3)] km/s and the acceleration is [a(4)] km/s2.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB functions for calculating the first and the second derivative of the function.

worksheet.stem:
The following data were collected for the distance traveled versus time for a rocket.

 

t, s 0 25 50 75 100 125
y, km 0 32 58 78 92 100

 

Estimate the first-derivative and the second-derivative using the M-file developed in the previous question of the same section. (Round the final solution for velocity to two decimal places and acceleration to four decimal places.)

 

The velocity at t = [a(2)] s is __a__ km/s and acceleration is __b__ km/s2.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file tested for the data in the table gives the following values.

 

function [dydx, d2ydx2] = diffeq(x,y)
n = length (x) ;
if length(y)~=n, error('x and y must be same length'), end
if any(diff(diff(x))~=0), error('unequal spacing'), end
if length(x)<4, error('at least 4 values required'), end
dx=x(2)-x(1);
for i=1:n
    if i==1
        dydx(i)=(-y(i+2)+4*y(i+1)-3*y(i))/dx/2;
        d2ydx2(i)=(-y(i+3)+4*y(i+2)-5*y(i+1)+2*y(i))/dx^2;
    elseif i==n
        dydx(i)=(3*y(i)-4*y(i-1)+y(i-2))/dx/2;
        d2ydx2(i)=(2*y(i)-5*y(i-1)+4*y(i-2)-y(i-3))/dx^2;
    else
        dydx(i)=(y(i+1)-y(i-1))/dx/2;
        d2ydx2(i)=(y(i+1)-2*y(i)+y(i-1))/dx^2;
    end
end
subplot(2,1,1);plot(x,dydx);grid;title('First derivatives')
subplot(2,1,2);plot(x,d2ydx2) ;grid;title('Second derivatives')

 

The MATLAB session is as follows:

 


>> t=[0 25 50 75 100 125];
>> y=[0 32 58 78 92 100];
>> [dydx, d2ydx2] = diffeq(t,y)

dydx =

    1.4000    1.1600    0.9200    0.6800    0.4400    0.2000


d2ydx2 =

   -0.0096   -0.0096   -0.0096   -0.0096   -0.0096   -0.0096

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The inflection points occur at x = –1 and 1.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB function for finding the inflection points.

worksheet.stem:
The normal distribution of the function is defined as

 

%media:formula150.mml%

 

Use MATLAB to determine the inflection points of the function. (Round the final answers to the nearest integer and enter the values in increasing order.)

 

The inflection points of the function occur at x = __a__ and __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The MATLAB script for finding the inflection points is given below.

>> x=-2:.1:2;
>> f=@(x) 1/sqrt(2*pi)*exp(-(x.^2)/2);
>> y=f(x);
>> d=diff(y)./diff(x);
>> x=-1.95:.1:1.95;
>> d2=diff(d)./diff(x);
>> x=-1.9:.1:1.9;
>> plot(x,d2);grid

 

%media:16.jpg%

 

Thus, inflection points (d2y/dx2 = 0) occur at –1 and 1.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The inflection point occurs at x = –1 and 1.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the method for finding the inflection points.

worksheet.stem:
The following data were generated from the normal distribution shown in the table below.

 

x –2 –1.5 –1 –0.5 0 0.5 1 1.5 2
f(x) 0.05399 0.12952 0.24197 0.35207 0.39894 0.35207 0.24197 0.12952 0.05399

 

Use MATLAB to estimate the inflection points of these data. (Round the answer to the nearest integer and enter the values in increasing order.)

 

The inflection points occur at x = __a__ and __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The MATLAB script for finding the inflection points of the data is given below.

>> x=[-2 -1.5 -1 -0.5 0 0.5 1 1.5 2];
>> y=[0.05399 0.12952 0.24197 0.35207 0.39894 0.35207 0.24197 0.12952 0.05399];
>> d=diff(y)./diff(x);
>> x=-1.75:.5:1.75;
>> d2=diff(d)./diff(x);
>> x=-1.5:.5:1.5;
>> plot(x,d2);grid

 

%media:21.017.jpg%

 

Thus, inflection points (d2y/dx2 = 0) occur at –1 and 1.

worksheet.stem:

0.50

worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following M-file can be used for finding the first-order derivatives and the second-order derivatives.

 

%Centered Finite Difference First & Second Derivatives of Order O(dx^2)
%Using diff(y)
dx=1.;
y=[1.4 2.1 3.3 4.8 6.8 6.6 8.6 7.5 8.9 10.9 10];
dyf=diff(y);
% First Derivative Centered FD using diff
n=length(y);
for i=1:n-2
  dydxc(i)=(dyf(i+1)+dyf(i))/(2*dx);
end
%Second Derivative Centered FD using diff
dy2dx2c=diff(dyf)/(dx*dx);
fprintf('first derivative \n'); fprintf('%f\n', dydxc)
fprintf('second derivative \n'); fprintf('%f\n', dy2dx2c)

worksheet.stem:
Flick's first diffusion law states that mass flux = –D (dc / dx), where mass flux = the quantity of mass that passes across a unit area per unit time (g/cm2/s), D = a diffusion coefficient (cm2/s), c = concentration (g/cm3), and x = distance (cm). An environmental engineer measures the following concentration of a pollutant in the pore waters of sediments underlying a lake (x = 0 at the sediment-water interface and increases downward).

 

x, cm 0 1 3
c, 10–6 g/cm3 0.06 0.32 0.6

 

Use the best numerical differentiation technique available to estimate the derivative at x = 0. Employ this estimate in conjunction with the given equation, to compute the mass flux of pollutant out of the sediments and into the overlying waters (D = 1.52 × 10−6 cm2/s). For a lake with 3.6 × 106 m2 of sediments, how much pollutant would be transported into the lake over a year’s time? (Round the mass flux to two decimal places and the mass transported to three decimal places.)

 

The mass flux is __a__ × 10–13 g/cm2s.

The mass transported is __b__ kg.

The first derivative at 0 is computed using the unequally spaced data method of numerical differentiation as shown below.

 

%media:formula38.mml%

 

The mass flux is computed below.

 

%media:formula43.mml%

 

The negative sign connotes transport from the sediments into the lake. The amount of mass transported into the lake is computed below.

 

%media:formula44.mml%

hint.value: Recall the formula for calculating the coefficient of thermal conductivity.

worksheet.stem:
Fourier’s law is used routinely by architectural engineers to determine heat flow through walls. The following temperatures are measured from the surface (x = 0) into a stone wall.

 

x, m 0 0.08 0.16
T, ºC 20.2 17 15

 

Compute the coefficient of thermal conductivity, k, if the flux at x = 0 is 60 W/m2. (Round the final answer to one decimal place.)

 

The coefficient of thermal conductivity when the surface value is 0 is __a__ W/(ºC·m).
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The given values are equally spaced and the changes are equal. Thus, a first-order approximation can be used to determine the slope at x = 0 as calculated below using the given table.

 

%media:formula54.mml%

 

The coefficient of thermal conductivity is estimated as k = –60 W/m2/ (–25 ºC/m) = 2.4 W/(ºC·m).

The surface value is changed to 20.2. For this case, the second-order forward difference formula is used to compute the derivative as shown below.

 

%media:formula55.mml%

 

The coefficient of thermal conductivity is estimated as k = –60 W/m2/(–47.5oC/m) = 1.26 W/(oC·m).

%media:formula96.mml%

 

where Z = the total depth (m). Determine the average concentration based on the following data:

P, atm V, L

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The order of the polynomial is 4.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the method of numerical differentiation for finding the derivatives.

worksheet.stem:
The following data for the specific heat of benzene were generated with an nth-order polynomial. Use the numerical differentiation to determine n.

 

T, K 300 400 500 600 700 800 900 1000
Cp, kJ/(kmol·k) 82.888 112.136 136.933 157.744 175.036 189.273 200.923 210.450

 

(Round the final answer to the nearest whole number.)

The order of the polynomial is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following script determines first through fourth derivative estimates by taking differences of differences. A plot of the results is also generated.


T=[300 400 500 600 700 800 900 1000];
Cp=[82.888 112.136 136.933 157.744 175.036 189.273 200.923 210.450];
dCp=diff(Cp)./diff(T);
n=length(T);
Tm=(T(1:n-1)+T(2:n))./2;
dCp2=diff(dCp)./diff(Tm);
n2=length(Tm);
Tm2=(Tm(1:n2-1)+Tm(2:n2))./2;
dCp3=diff(dCp2)./diff(Tm2);
n3=length(Tm2);
Tm3=(Tm2(1:n3-1)+Tm2(2:n3))./2;
dCp4=diff(dCp3)./diff(Tm3);
n4=length(Tm3);
Tm4=(Tm3(1:n4-1)+Tm3(2:n4))./2;

subplot(4,1,1),plot(Tm,dCp)
grid,xlim([min(T) max(T)]),title('first derivative')
subplot(4,1,2),plot(Tm2,dCp2)
grid,xlim([min(T) max(T)]),title('second derivative')
subplot(4,1,3),plot(Tm3,dCp3)
grid,xlim([min(T) max(T)]),title('third derivative')
subplot(4,1,4),plot(Tm4,dCp4)
grid,xlim([min(T) max(T)]),title('fourth derivative')

 

%media:32.jpg%

 

The fact that (1) the second derivative appears linear, (2) the third derivative is close to being constant, and (3) the fourth derivative oscillates in a random fashion close to zero suggests that the data were generated with a fourth-order polynomial (which in fact was the case).

worksheet.stem:
The specific heat at constant pressure cp [J/(kg · K)] of an ideal gas is related to enthalpy by

 

%media:formula121.mml%

 

where h = enthalpy (kJ/kg), and T = absolute temperature (K). The following enthalpies are provided for carbon dioxide (CO2) at several temperatures. Use these values to determine the specific heat in J/(kg · K) for each of the tabulated temperatures. Note that the atomic weights of carbon and oxygen are 12.011 and 15.9994 g/mol, respectively. (Round the final answers to one decimal place.)

 

T, K 750 800 900 1000
h, kJ/kmol 29,629 32,179 37,405 42,769

 

 

The specific heat at different values of temperature is

 

T, K Specific heat, (J/(kg · K))
750 __a__
800 __b__
900 __c__
1000 __d__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The method of unequally spaced data set is used to estimate the derivatives at each temperature using the MATLAB script shown below.

 

function dy=diffuneq(x,y)
% diffuneq: differentiation of unequally-spaced data
%  dy=diffuneq(func,x,es,maxit,varargin):
% input:
%   x = vector of independent variable
%   y = vector of dependent variable
% output:
%   dy = vector of derivative estimates


if nargin<2,error('at least 2 input arguments required'),end
n=length(x);
for i = 1:n
  dy(i) = dyuneq(x, y, n, x(i));
end
end


function dydx=dyuneq(x, y, n, xx)
if xx <= x(2)
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(1), x(2), x(3), y(1), y(2), y(3));
elseif xx >= x(n - 1)
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(n - 2), x(n - 1), x(n), y(n - 2), y(n - 1), y(n));
else
 for ii = 2:n - 2
  if xx >= x(ii) & xx <= x(ii + 1)
   if xx - x(ii) < x(ii+1) - xx
    %if the unknown is closer to the lower end of the range,
    %x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
    dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
y(ii), y(ii + 1));
   elseif xx - x(ii-1) == x(ii+1)-xx & x(ii)-x(ii-1)<x(ii+2)-x(ii+1)
  %if the unknown is at the midpoint of the range
% and if the interval below the range
  %is less than the interval above the range,
%  x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
y(ii), y(ii + 1));
else

  %otherwise, x(ii+1) is chosen as the middle point
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii), x(ii + 1), x(ii + 2), y(ii), y(ii + 1), ...
      y(ii + 2));
   end
   break
  end
 end
end
end


function dy=DyDx(x, x0, x1, x2, y0, y1, y2)
dy = y0 * (2 * x - x1 - x2) / (x0 - x1) / (x0 - x2) ...
     + y1 * (2 * x - x0 -x2) / (x1- x0) / (x1 - x2) ...
      + y2 * (2 * x - x0 - x1) / (x2 - x0)/ (x2 - x1);
end

This MATLAB file is used to find the specific heat.


>> T=[750 800 900 1000];
>> h=[29629 32179 37405 42769];
>> cp=diffuneq(T,h)
cp =
   50.5800  51.4200  52.9500  54.3300


These results, which have units of kJ/(kmol K), can be converted to the desired units as in

 

%media:formula127.mml%

 

>> cp=cp*1e3/(12.011+2*15.9994)


cp =
  1.0e+003 *
    1.1493 1.1684 1.2031 1.2345

worksheet.stem:
An nth-order rate law is often used to model chemical reactions that solely depend on the concentration of a single reactant:

 

%media:formula122.mml%

 

where c = concentration (mole), t = time (min), n = reaction order (dimensionless), and k = reaction rate (min−1 mole1−n). The differential method can be used to
evaluate the parameters k and n. This involves applying a logarithmic transform to the rate law to yield,

 

%media:formula123.mml%

 

Therefore, if the nth-order rate law holds, a plot of the log(−dc/dt) versus log c should yield a straight line with a slope of n and an intercept of log k. Use the differential method and linear regression to determine k and n for the following data for the conversion of ammonium cyanate to urea:

 

t, min 0 5 15 30 45
c, mole 0.750 0.594 0.420 0.291 0.223

 

(Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The value of k is __a__.

The value of n is __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following MATLAB function is used to find the values of the unknown parameters.

 

function dy=diffuneq(x,y)
% diffuneq: differentiation of unequally-spaced data
%  dy=diffuneq(func,x,es,maxit,varargin):
% input:
%   x = vector of independent variable
%   y = vector of dependent variable
% output:
%   dy = vector of derivative estimates


if nargin<2,error('at least 2 input arguments required'),end
n=length(x);
for i = 1:n
  dy(i) = dyuneq(x, y, n, x(i));
end
end


function dydx=dyuneq(x, y, n, xx)
if xx <= x(2)
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(1), x(2), x(3), y(1), y(2), y(3));
elseif xx >= x(n - 1)
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(n - 2), x(n - 1), x(n), y(n - 2), y(n - 1), y(n));
else
 for ii = 2:n - 2
  if xx >= x(ii) & xx <= x(ii + 1)
   if xx - x(ii) < x(ii+1) - xx
    %if the unknown is closer to the lower end of the range,
    %x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
    dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
y(ii), y(ii + 1));
   elseif xx - x(ii-1) == x(ii+1)-xx & x(ii)-x(ii-1)<x(ii+2)-x(ii+1)
  %if the unknown is at the midpoint of the range
% and if the interval below the range
  %is less than the interval above the range,
%  x(ii) will be chosen as the middle point
dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii - 1), x(ii), x(ii + 1), y(ii - 1), ...
y(ii), y(ii + 1));
else

  %otherwise, x(ii+1) is chosen as the middle point
  dydx = DyDx(xx, x(ii), x(ii + 1), x(ii + 2), y(ii), y(ii + 1), ...
      y(ii + 2));
   end
   break
  end
 end
end
end


function dy=DyDx(x, x0, x1, x2, y0, y1, y2)
dy = y0 * (2 * x - x1 - x2) / (x0 - x1) / (x0 - x2) ...
     + y1 * (2 * x - x0 -x2) / (x1- x0) / (x1 - x2) ...
      + y2 * (2 * x - x0 - x1) / (x2 - x0)/ (x2 - x1);
end

 

The following script determines dc/dt using an M-file that implements the first derivative using unequally spaced data set. Linear regression is then used to fit the log transformed equation. The best-fit parameters are then used to compute the model coefficients n and k with the following script:


>> t=[0 5 15 30 45];
>> c=[0.750 0.594 0.420 0.291 0.223];
>> dcdt=diffuneq(t,c)
>> p=polyfit(log10(c),log10(-dcdt),1)
>> n=p(1)
>> k=10^p(2)


dcdt =
  -0.0358  -0.0266  -0.0139  -0.0066  -0.0025
p =
   2.1419  -1.1121
n =
   2.1419
k =
   0.0773

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the numerical differentiation formulas for finding the first and second derivatives of the function.

worksheet.stem:
You measure the following deflections along the length of a simply supported uniform beam.

x, m 0 0.375 0.75 1.125 1.5 1.875 2.25 2.625 3
y, cm 0 –0.2571 –0.9484 –1.9689 –3.2262 –4.6414 –6.1503 –7.7051 –9.275

 

Employ numerical differentiation to compute the slope, the moment (in N m), the shear (in N) and the distributed load (in N/m). Use the following parameter values in the computation: E = 200 GPa, and I = 0.0003 m4. (Round the slope to four decimal places and moment, shear, and the distributed load to one decimal place.)

 

The slope of the uniform beam at x = [a(1)] and y = [a(2)] is __a__.

The moment of the uniform beam at x = [a(1)] and y = [a(2)] is __b__ N m.

The shear of the uniform beam at x = [a(1)] and y = [a(2)] is __c__ N.

The distributed load of the uniform beam at x = [a(1)] and y = [a(2)] is __d__ N/m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The slope, moment, shear, and the distributed load are given by following functions.

 

%media:formula155.mml%

 

The function Derivs can be used to determine the derivatives. Because the data are equispaced, the formulas of forward finite-difference, centered finite-difference, and the backward finite-difference can be used to determine the derivatives with the following functions. The function Diff1 determines first derivatives and Diff2 determines second derivatives.


function [dydx,d2ydx2,d3ydx3,d4ydx4]=Derivs(x,y)
clf
if any(diff(diff(x))~=0), error('unequal spacing'), end
if any(diff(x)<=0), error('not in ascending order'), end
dydx=DiffNum(x,y);
d2ydx2=DiffNum2(x,y);
d3ydx3=DiffNum(x,d2ydx2);
d4ydx4=DiffNum(x,d3ydx3);


function dydx=DiffNum(x,y)
n=length(x);
dydx=zeros(n);dx=x(2)-x(1);
dydx(1)=(-3*y(1)+4*y(2)-y(3))/(2*dx);
for i = 2:n-1
  dydx(i)=(y(i+1)-y(i-1))/(2*dx);
end
dydx(n)=(3*y(n)-4*y(n-1)+y(n-2))/(2*dx);
dydx=dydx(:,1);
end

 

function d2ydx2=DiffNum2(x,y)
n=length(x);
d2ydx2=zeros(n);dx=x(2)-x(1);
d2ydx2(1)=(-y(4)+4*y(3)-5*y(2)+2*y(1))/dx^2;
for i = 2:n-1
 d2ydx2(i)=(y(i+1)-2*y(i)+y(i-1))/dx^2;
end
d2ydx2(n)=(2*y(n)-5*y(n-1)+4*y(n-2)-y(n-3))/dx^2;
d2ydx2=d2ydx2(:,1);
end

 

The following script calls the function to generate and plot the derivatives.

 

clear,clc,clf
x=[0 0.375 0.75 1.125 1.5 1.875 2.25 2.625 3];
y=[0 -0.2571 -0.9484 -1.9689 -3.2262 -4.6414 -6.1503 -7.7051 -9.275];
y=y/100;
E=200e9;I=0.0003;
[dydx,d2ydx2,d3ydx3,d4ydx4]=Derivs(x,y);
M=E*I*d2ydx2;V=E*I*d3ydx3;wx=E*I*d4ydx4;
subplot(5,1,1)
plot(x,y,'o-')
subplot(5,1,2)
plot(x,dydx)
subplot(5,1,3)
plot(x,M)
subplot(5,1,4)
plot(x,V)
subplot(5,1,5)
plot(x,wx)
z=[x' y' dydx M V wx]';
fprintf(' x y dy/dx M(x) V(x) d4y/dx4\n');
fprintf('%10.4f %10.4f %10.4f %10.1f %10.1f %10.1f\n',z);

sectionBreak.stem:
The gradient of the function z = f(x, y) is given by the following equation:

 

%media:formula160.mml%

 

where %media:formula161.mml% and %media:formula162.mml% are the first-order partial derivatives with respect to x and y, respectively, which are given as component vectors. The gradient function is useful for determining partial derivatives in two or more dimensions. In particular, it can be used in conjunction with other MATLAB functions to produce visualizations of vector fields. 

A grid of points in the x-y plane can be generated using the foregoing equations to draw the gradient vector at each point. The result would be a field of arrows indicating the steepest route to the peak from any point. Such graphical representations are so useful that MATLAB has a special function, called quiver, to create such plots. A simple representation of its syntax is


quiver(x,y,u,v)


where x and y are matrices containing the position coordinates and u and v are matrices containing the partial derivatives. The negative of the gradient function is used with the quiver function to get the plots.

The gradient of the function z = f(x, y) is given by the following equation:

 

%media:formula157.mml%

 

where %media:formula158.mml% and %media:formula159.mml% are the first-order partial derivatives with respect to x and y, respectively, which are given as component vectors. The gradient function is useful for determining partial derivatives in two or more dimensions. In particular, it can be used in conjunction with other MATLAB functions to produce visualizations of vector fields.
A grid of points in the x-y plane can be generated using the foregoing equations to draw the gradient vector at each point. The result would be a field of arrows indicating the steepest route to the peak from any point. Such graphical representations are so useful that MATLAB has a special function, called quiver, to create such plots. A simple representation of its syntax is


quiver(x,y,u,v)


where x and y are matrices containing the position coordinates and u and v are matrices containing the partial derivatives. The negative of the gradient function is used with the quiver function to get the plots.

Employ the gradient function for finding the partial derivatives and then use the quiver function to superimpose the contour plot for the MATLAB peaks function over ranges of both x and y from – 3 to 3.
